newsitem.title: JAPAN: Hokkaido Takushoku, Hokkaido Bank say to merge.
newsitem.headline: Hokkaido Takushoku, Hokkaido Bank say to merge.

text.p: Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd, Japan's 10th-largest commercial bank, and the smaller regional bank Hokkaido Bank Ltd said on Tuesday that they plan to merge in April 1998.
The two banks said in a joint statement they had decided to start preparations for the merger and that it would be carried out on an equal basis.
Hokkaido Takushoku will be the surviving entity after the merger, the two banks said in their joint statement. Both are headquartered in Sapporo, Hokkaido's largest city.
Hokkaido Bank will be disbanded and the new bank's name will probably be Shin-Hokkaido Bank, they said.
Hokkaido Takushoku also said that it would withdraw from overseas operations by March 1998.
It said the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd would help in providing overseas services to its clients after the pullout.
Hokkaid Takushoku said it would continue offering foreign exchange and overseas investment services at its branches in Japan.
It said it would post an appraisal loss of 61 billion yen on its securities holdings in 1996/97.
The two merging banks said in the joint statement that the merger would create a super-regional bank which could contribute to the growth of their clients and the regional economy.
They said the banks must be able to provide advanced financial services and have strong financial condition amid the era of global competition and deregulation in Japan's financial industry.
"We have reached the conclusion that the merger on an equal bases will best respond to the needs of the times," the statement said.
Hokkaido Takushoku Bank had total assets of 10.12 trillion yen as of the end of September 1996, while Hokkaido Bank had assets worth 3.35 trillion yen.
The two banks' staffs totaled 8,473 as of the end of September.
